diagrams.description: Biological Conservation is the scientific discipline dedicated to protecting biodiversity, including species, genetic diversity, and ecosystems, from extinction and degradation. Its primary objective is to preserve Earth's biological diversity through understanding threats, implementing protection strategies, and promoting sustainable human-nature relationships. Core domains include: threat assessment (habitat loss and fragmentation, overexploitation, invasive species, pollution, climate change), conservation strategies (protected areas establishment, species recovery programs, habitat restoration, ex-situ conservation), genetic diversity preservation (population viability analysis, genetic management, seed banks, cryopreservation), ecosystem conservation (ecosystem services protection, keystone species management, ecological integrity maintenance), and community engagement (sustainable livelihoods, indigenous knowledge integration, environmental education, participatory conservation). The conservation process involves biodiversity assessment and monitoring, threat identification, conservation planning (systematic conservation planning, prioritization), intervention implementation, and adaptive management. These elements integrate through ecology, genetics, and social sciences to create protected area networks, species reintroduction programs, habitat corridors, sustainable resource management, and community-based conservation that safeguard biodiversity for future generations.
